p: Despite a substantial body of literature on the health effects of mitigation strategies [ 63, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68], there are few examples of integrated analyses of mitigation and adaptation strategies. In some cases, these can lead to explicit tradeoffs [ 69]. For example, the most effective adaptation strategy for preventing heat-related morbidity and mortality is to increase access to air conditioning [ 57]. However, without sufficient renewable electricity generation, such a strategy will result in an increase in greenhouse gas emissions, directly conflicting with mitigation goals.
